Award.AwardTitle: Efficacy Study of Project-Based Inquiry Science

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research and development project studies the impact of Project-Based Inquiry Science (PBIS) on 8th grade students across several large school districts. The PIs include researchers at SRI International's Center for Technology in Learning and Joseph Krajcik of the University of Michigan, one of the original developers of PBIS. NSF funded the development of PBIS over the past two decades, with major investments made in the design of materials and with associated teacher professional development designed to help teachers understand the content of the unit and how to teach it. PBIS is a comprehensive, 3-year middle school science curriculum that focuses on standards-based science content and that uses project-based inquiry science units to help students learn. Prior small-scale studies of PBIS have shown positive impact on student achievement and motivation, and on teacher use of reform-based instruction. The research questions explored are:
1. Efficacy. What is the impact of PBIS on student learning? To what extent do students in PBIS perform better than non-PBIS students on measures of learning?
2. Enactment and teacher practice. What is the impact of the curriculum on teaching quality? What is the fidelity of classroom implementation? How does the depth and level of implementation relate to student outcomes?

The study involves both quantitative and qualitative methods; the use of an experimental design allows estimates of causal impacts when combining professional development with the curriculum materials. This is a randomized control trial to test the efficacy of PBIS in 36 schools total and with 72 teachers (18 schools and 36 teachers per condition), and affecting approximately 8,500 8th grade students. The dependent variables for students include results on state-level science test scores and measures of their ability to explain and design in the context of the curriculum units. Mediational analysis measures the association between contextual factors such as fidelity of implementation and quality of the professional development experience and student learning, allowing a deeper understanding of results.

This work is critical to the ongoing effort to support standards-based curriculum reform in science. PBIS has enjoyed some success in urban settings with diverse groups of students, including those from historically underrepresented groups in science, and now moves to larger scale. This curriculum is among a small number of science curriculum initiatives that are at a stage in the research and development cycle where implementation efforts are focused on scaling to a broader range of schools and districts. The curriculum units are based on design principles drawn from theory and research on how students learn and are aligned with learning goals found in state and national standards. Project outcomes provide evidence about the effects of a published and available inquiry-based science curriculum.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Efficacy Study of Project-Based Inquiry Science project was an effort to design and conduct an experimental study of the Project-Based Inquiry Science (PBIS) curriculum’s efficacy. PBIS is a middle school project-based science curriculum that engages students in using science and engineering practices to investigate and explain the natural world and design solutions to problems. SRI International led the project in collaboration with researchers at the University of Colorado Boulder and Michigan State University.

A unique feature of the study’s design was an analytic focus on the conditions needed to implement the curriculum in ways that improve student learning in light of the new national science education standards. To measure the impact of the curriculum materials, the project team conducted a randomized controlled trial in sixth grade science classrooms across 42 schools in one large urban school district. Schools were randomly assigned to either a treatment or comparison condition; all sixth-grade science teachers in a given school had the same assignment. Teachers in the treatment condition implemented the project-based science curriculum and received professional development on the vision underlying the new standards, as well as in the use of the curriculum materials. Teachers in the comparison condition implemented their regular district-adopted textbook and also received professional development on the vision underlying the new standards. Science teachers in both conditions covered the same science topics.

Research questions guiding the study were focused on student learning, classroom implementation, and teaching practice:

1. Student learning. What is the impact of project-based curriculum materials on student science learning? To what extent do students in PBIS perform better than non-PBIS students on measures of learning?

2. Implementation and teaching practice. What is the impact of the curriculum on teaching quality? What is the fidelity of classroom implementation? How does the depth and level of implementation relate to student outcomes? How does district-level involvement and support relate to implementation?

To conduct a valid evaluation, the project team had to develop and test new assessments that could measure next generation science learning goals. The assessment items required students to demonstrate understanding of important science ideas by engaging in science practices. The piloting of the tests showed that the items could be reliably scored and that they were sensitive to instruction, two key criteria for validity in assessments.

The project team developed and administered surveys and weekly online instructional logs to document the implementation by teachers of the curriculum materials. In order to better understand how the project-based science materials were used in classrooms, a randomly selected subsample of teachers in the treatment condition were asked to self-video record their classroom instruction. The team also interviewed treatment teachers and district stakeholders to understand the organizational conditions for implementing the curriculum.

The study was conducted over two years. First year results indicated a significant positive impact for students who participated in the project-based science curriculum. This positive effect could be attributed to consistent implementation and district-level support for new forms of instruction related to new standards. Noteworthy is that between the first and second year of the study, the district and state shifted away from pursuing the new science standards. Second year results indicated that there was no significant difference in learning outcomes across conditions. This finding could be attributed to the shift in district-level guidance for science instruction. Importantly, the overall results show that project-based science curriculum materials can help students achieve next generation learning outcomes when there is coherence with district policy and guidance about instruction. The study findings suggest that coherence among curriculum materials, district involvement, and support for new forms of instruction may be necessary to support effective implementation.

This study was the first to examine science curriculum materials with measures that are aligned to the vision of the new science standards. Moreover, at the time this study was conducted, it was one of only a handful of rigorously designed impact studies that also examined implementation and effects on teaching practice systematically. This study adds to our understanding of how district-level involvement relates to the efficacy of curriculum. Furthermore, this research is important for moving us toward increased understanding of how to effectively study and support teaching and learning in school settings that will be trying to implement the next generation of science curriculum materials.
